title: Liverpool legend John Aldridge says Reds must learn how win ugly to end 'unacceptable' run of form
text:
Sport Liverpool legend John Aldridge says Reds must learn how win ugly to end 'unacceptable' run of form The former Liverpool striker saw his old side lose 2-0 to Hull at the weekend - their fourth loss in five games Share The Reds suffered another loss at the weekend (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Former Liverpool striker John Aldridge says his old side must learn how win ugly in order to end their current poor run of form. 
The Reds have lost four of their last five games, including a 2-0 reverse at Hull at the weekend and Aldridge believes that Jurgen Klopp's men must show more grit if they are to get out of their current slump. 
"I thought we’d struggle at Hull but by that I mean, I thought we might labour to a 1-1 all draw but the run that we’ve had is unacceptable," he wrote in his Liverpool Echo column . 
"We’ve got to man up. You don’t become a bad side overnight. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jurgen Klopp rages at poor Liverpool showing Share this video Watch Next 
"Hull to be fair have been playing really well of late so nothing should have been taken for granted but when you’re playing these so-called lesser sides you’ve got to earn your right to play but we look like we haven’t got too many battlers at the moment. 
"They look like they’re just willing to roll over and for a manager that’s worrying. 
"It’s happening all the time but for me they’ve just got to win ugly. 
A lack of clean sheets has been a problem for the Reds this season, with their last one coming before Christmas. The Reds have not kept a Premier League clean sheet since December 19 (Photo: Andrew Powell) Klopp has seen his side fall out of the Champions League places (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) 
"We can’t keep a clean sheet but we’ve got to try and instil that because you’re going to struggle to win games when you keep conceding goals," he continued. 
"They’ve got to roll their sleeves up and they can’t feel sorry for themselves. 
"These players are on ridiculous amounts of money and for all the joy they gave us up to Christmas the last month has been unbearable to be a Liverpool fan." 
Next up for the Reds is a home clash against title contenders Tottenham on Saturday, before a trip to struggling champions Leicester and a home clash against Arsenal.
